title: McDonald's Could Weaken Further in the Weeks Ahead
text:
On Mad Money's "No-Huddle Offense" Tuesday night, Jim Cramer wanted to take a closer look at McDonald's Corp. (MCD) , which fell 2.65% on Tuesday. Hitting the stock was a research note from JP Morgan analysts, saying that same-store sales would be disappointing this quarter. The analysts are confident that estimates are too high for the quarter, Cramer said. McDonald's is losing market share to competitors and delivery will not be as impactful as investors hope.

This is a tough call, Cramer said, pointing out that the analyst still has a buy rating on the stock. For his part, Cramer agrees that McDonald's stock is a buy. But that's part of the problem, as almost every analyst has a buy rating on MCD. That means it could get hit by downgrades at some point.

If you're a long-term investor in McDonald's, Cramer suggests riding out the possible storm. Let's check out the charts and indicators to see what downside risk may be cooking.

In this daily bar chart of MCD, below, we can see that the month of September was a time of weakness. MCD gapped below the flat 50-day moving average line in early September and more recently failed at the underside of the line. Prices are close to making a new low for the move down from the August high.

The On-Balance-Volume (OBV) line is still in an uptrend but close to turning lower.

The Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) oscillator is below the zero line in sell territory.

In this weekly bar chart of MCD, below, we can see a mixed picture. Prices are still above the rising 40-week moving average line but we know this is a lagging indicator.

The weekly OBV line has been flat the past three months and that is a bearish divergence when compared to the price action.

The trend-following MACD oscillator crossed to a take profits sell signal at the beginning of September.

In this Point and Figure chart of MCD, below, we can see a modest downside price target in the $193 area. If this price target is reached it means the rising 200-day average line has been broken.

Bottom line strategy: To me, risk is a function in part of your purchase price. If you are long MCD from much lower levels a pullback to the $193 area is not terrible. But if a profit could turn into a loss you should take action.
